cluster_relations.rel_desc: The butterfly life cycle includes the larval (caterpillar) stage.
remarks: Order relative to egg stage captured in separate relation.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: The butterfly life cycle includes the pupal (chrysalis) stage.

qualifiers.TemporalQualifier: after larval stage, before adult stage

remarks: Order relative to larval and adult stages captured separately.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: The chrysalis is the physical casing that characterizes the pupal (chrysalis) stage of a butterfly.
remarks: Relation mainly to bind the physical casing (chrysalis) to the abstract life-cycle stage.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that a life cycle concept includes a specific life-cycle stage as one of its constituent phases.
args.justification: Both relations link the overall butterfly life cycle to specific stages (larval, pupal) as constituent phases; a single canonical predicate 'has_life_cycle_stage' captures this part–whole life-cycle structure without encoding order, which is already in qualifiers.
These relations express membership of particular stages within an organism's life cycle; they form a coherent family distinct from generic composition or hierarchy relations.
The primary semantics is that the life cycle is composed of these stages; temporal ordering is captured by qualifiers, while the edge itself is part–whole composition.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that a concrete physical structure or form is the physical manifestation or casing of a more abstract process, state, or stage.
args.justification: The relation links the concrete chrysalis to the abstract pupal stage, where the chrysalis serves as the physical casing/embodiment of that stage; this is best modeled as a physical-manifestation predicate rather than composition or simple identity.

This relation type connects an abstract life-cycle stage to its concrete physical form, fitting a broader class of links where physical entities serve as embodiments or casings of abstract states or phases.

The link expresses a representational/embodiment identity between an abstract stage and its concrete casing rather than causal, spatial, or purely compositional semantics; among the broad groups available, IDENTITY best captures this representational equivalence.
